column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.3
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Causalstatements|
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Ecosystem|
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Focalpoint|
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Locationofstudy|
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Mainhypothesisandcorrespondingresults|
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Method|
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Reccomendationsandsuggestions|
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Researchquestions|
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Timeperiodofstudy|

#Text=Negative plant_soil feedback influences a dominant seeded species, Western yarrow (Achillea millefolium), in grassland restoration\rCharles W Casper,�Mary Ellyn DuPre,�Morgan L McLeod,�Rebecca A Bunn,�John L Maron,�Philip W Ramsey,�Ylva Lekberg\rFirst published: 10 September 2024\r�\rhttps://doi.org/10.1111/rec.14271\rAuthor contributions: CWC, YL, PWR conceived of the study; YL, JLM, MLM initiated the field experiment; CWC, YL, MED, JLM, MLM collected data; YL conducted greenhouse experiments; MED conducted molecular and bioinformatic analyses; CWC, MED, RAB conducted statistical analyses; CWC, YL, PWR, MED wrote the first draft; all co_authors edited the manuscript.
#Text=Coordinating Editor: Louise Egerton_Warburton\rSECTIONS.
#Text=Abstract.

#Text=Plant community ecology guides restoration of degraded lands, yet seed_based restorations sometimes fail or result in unpredictable outcomes, necessitating a better understanding of community trajectory and stability.
#Text=Western yarrow (Achillea millefolium) declined suddenly in two separate restoration projects after initial high relative abundance.

#Text=To assess the potential role of soil pathogens, we surveyed plant and soil fungal communities in these restorations, and used an 8_year_old field experiment that crossed yarrow planted in varying densities with a fungicide treatment.
#Text=Two greenhouse experiments then evaluated whether the suppressive effect in yarrow soil spread to native species used in restoration.

#Text=Lower yarrow cover in a restoration project 5 years compared to 3 years after seeding coincided with higher relative abundance of fungal taxa that can cause disease, particularly Crown_rot fungi (Paraphoma�spp).
#Text=�Paraphoma�increased over time in experimental plots and coincided with yarrow decline.
#Text=Decline onset was density_dependent, occurring faster in plant communities where yarrow density was higher.
#Text=Fungicide applications altered fungal pathogen communities and promoted yarrow cover relative to control plots.
#Text=In the greenhouse, yarrow grew larger with fungicide, consistent with suppression of fungal pathogens.
#Text=However, biomass of natives grown in yarrow_conditioned soil was not affected by fungicides, suggesting pathogens did not spread.

#Text=The rapid establishment and competitive nature of yarrow, followed by pathogen_induced decline, make it an attractive early transitional  bridge species,   so long as its pathogens are species_specific.
#Text=Our results suggest negative plant_soil feedback can drive rapid decline of individual species, and considering plant�soil feedback could improve restoration predictability.

#Text=Implications for Practice\r* Early transitional or so_called  bridge species   used in restoration at high densities may accumulate pathogens.\r* Density_dependent pathogen accumulation may be predictable and could control bridge species without herbicides, mowing, or other management.\r* Open niche space following suppression may allow for staggered introduction of later successional species if pathogens are host_specific and do not negatively affect other native plants.\r* Monitoring soil pathogens may give practitioners a better understanding of the sources of success or failure in restoration outcomes.
#Text=Introduction.

#Text=Restoration ecology emerged from plant community ecology (Temperton et al�2004; Palmer et al�2016) and tends to be plant_centric with community assembly and succession theories guiding selection of seed mixtures and planting order (Sheley et al�2006; Wainwright et al�2018).
#Text=However, seed_based restorations sometimes fail or result in unexpected outcomes (Shackleford et al�2021).

#Text=Although drought (Hardegree et al�2018), temperature extremes (James et al�2019), non_native invasive plants (Martin & Wilsey�2014), or cryptic demographic and biotic filters (James et al�2011) contribute, often the causes of failure are complex or simply unknown (Svejcar et al�2017).
#Text=As such, restoration ecologists continue to search for factors that can improve predictability.
#Text=Plants influence both abiotic and biotic properties of soils, which affect their growth and competitive interactions with other plants (Bever et al�1997).

#Text=These so_called plant�soil feedbacks can drive plant succession, influence relative abundance and diversity of plant species in communities, and either aid or prevent non_native plant invasions (Kulmatiski et al�2012; van der Putten et al�2013).

#Text=Plant�soil feedback can affect plant performance as strongly as competition (Lekberg et al�2018), yet it is rarely addressed or invoked in ecological restoration, even though its potential has been discussed for some time (Eviner & Hawkes�2008; Harris�2009).
#Text=Most plant�soil feedback studies have been conducted under controlled greenhouse conditions (Lekberg et al�2018), although the role of soil biota has also been documented in the field.
#Text=For example, Wubs et al (2016) showed that large_scale soil inoculations can steer plant and microbial community development toward different target communities.

#Text=Similarly, inoculations by arbuscular mycorrhizal fungi (AMF), which colonize most plant roots and aid in nutrient uptake and possibly other services in exchange for plant carbon, have been used in prairie restoration (Koziol & Bever�2017).
#Text=In addition to AMF, plant pathogens are important players in plant�soil feedback.
#Text=They tend to be more host_specific than AMF but can also affect plant diversity (Thakur et al�2021).
#Text=In some instances, rare species suffer more from pathogens than abundant species (Klironomos�2002; Mangan et al�2010).
#Text=In other instances, pathogens accumulate in a density_dependent fashion, suppressing growth more for abundant than less abundant species (Maron et al�2011; van Ruijven et al�2020).
#Text=Pathogens affect early seral species more than late seral species (Kardol et al�2006), which contributes to successional shifts in plant communities.
#Text=But to what extent plant pathogens affect assembly processes and succession in communities undergoing restoration is not completely understood.

#Text=Bridge species are used during initial phases of restoration to stabilize soil, compete with weeds, or ameliorate poor site conditions, which often occur on degraded lands with low plant density or simplified communities resulting from overgrazing, mining activities, or herbicide applications (Kildisheva et al�2016; Svejcar et al�2017).
#Text=These early, transitional species are often planted at high densities to preempt niche space from undesirable species (Fukami�2015; Delory et al�2019).

#Text=Due to their short lifespan and high density, they are probably susceptible to pathogens, but whether the abundance of bridge species is affected by pathogens is little known (Kulmatiski et al�2017).
#Text=Western yarrow (Achillea millefolium�L. var.
#Text=�occidentalis�DC., hereafter yarrow) is a common species used in restoration of semiarid grasslands (detailed life history description in�Supplement S1).
#Text=Yarrow usually establishes quickly (Lambert et al�2011; but see Jensen et al�2022), competes well with common grassland invaders, and is available in large quantities.
#Text=It also associates with AMF and has the capacity to build AMF abundance in degraded soils (Wilson & Hartnett�1998; Sonneman et al�2012).
#Text=However, yarrow can also generate negative plant�soil feedback when grown in monocultures or intraspecific conditioned soils (Maron et al�2011; Jing et al�2015).
#Text=Yarrow reproduces from both rhizomes and seeds, so defining a lifespan for an individual is not straightforward (Bourd t et al�1985).
#Text=Typically, yarrow is not classified as a short_lived ruderal species (Aleksoff�1999), yet we have observed a yarrow boom and bust after 3_5 years across several restoration projects (Fig�1).
#Text=This rapid establishment and predictable decline without management interventions could make yarrow a promising bridge species.
#Text=Figure 1\rTime series photos from the Older restoration site (seeded 2015) on MPG Ranch.
#Text=White flowering yarrow corymbs already abundant in 2017 peak in 2018.
#Text=Between 2018 and 2019, many plants were in the process of dying, as indicated by the substantial reduction in flowering yarrow, with most flower stalks in 2019 being dead_standing from 2018.

#Text=Consequently, we asked: (1) is yarrow successful at establishing from seed relative to other native species commonly included in restoration seed mixes; (2) is the sudden yarrow decline due to soil pathogen accumulation; (3) is yarrow decline in_part a density_dependent process; (4) do soil pathogens spread to other native plants used in restoration  To address these questions, we surveyed plant species cover and characterized fungal and oomycete (another important group of soil pathogens, including�Phytophthora�and�Pythium; Derevnina et al�2016) communities in two restoration areas seeded 17 months apart and where yarrow cover was visibly less 5 years compared to 3 years after seeding.

#Text=We then took advantage of an ongoing field experiment where plant cover data and soil had been collected over time in communities planted with different densities of yarrow and heterospecifics and crossed with a fungicide treatment.

#Text=Finally, a series of greenhouse experiments explored the direct and indirect effects of fungicides to help interpret results from the field experiment and assess whether soil biota cultured by yarrow suppressed the growth of four plants commonly used in restoration.
#Text=Methods.

#Text=Study Area\rField surveys and experiments took place on MPG Ranch, a 6400 ha private conservation property and former cattle ranch in Western Montana, United States (46degrees40 48.92 N, 114degrees1 40.73 W,�https://www.mpgranch.com; Fig�S1).

#Text=Large areas are undergoing restoration from monocultures of Crested wheatgrass (Agropyron cristatum) and other introduced forage grass back to native cool_season bunchgrass communities typical of this area (Durham et al�2017).
#Text=Yarrow was detected at 23 out of 98 never_cultivated survey points on MPG Ranch in 2016 and comprised 1.5% average total foliar cover where it occurred (unpublished data).
#Text=Annual precipitation averaged 316 mm and mean temperature 7.5degreesC between 1991 and 2020 based on a weather station 25 km south of MPG Ranch (www.ncei.noaa.gov).
#Text=Elevation ranged from 995 m at the field experiment to 1080 m at the restoration sites.
#Text=Soils are fine to gravelly, loamy mollisols in the Bigarm gravelly loam series (www.nrcs.usda.gov).

#Text=Field Survey of Ongoing Restoration\rTo examine the relationship between soil pathogens, yarrow's establishment, and subsequent decline during restoration (questions 1 & 2), we chose two adjacent sites (15 and 24 ha) with different restoration ages (seeded in 2015 and 2017) and yarrow cover based on visual observations (low vs. high) with otherwise similar soil conditions (Table�S1), elevation, and aspect.
#Text=While restoration age only differed by 17 months, hereafter we refer to these sites as Older and Younger.
#Text=Time lapse photos of the Older site indicate visual declines in yarrow cover over time (Fig�1).
#Text=Site History\rRestoration activities during and after seeding are described in detail in�Supplement S1.
#Text=Briefly, the Older site was seeded on 3 November 2015, and the Younger site was seeded on 4 April 2017.
#Text=Seed mixes are shown in Table S3a�c.
#Text=We used Eagle germplasm Western yarrow (Granite Seed Company, Lehi, UT, U.S.A.), recommended for quick establishment and no known detrimental diseases (Lambert et al�2011).
#Text=Yarrow was seeded at 57 seeds/m2�at the Older site and 97 seeds/m2�at the Younger site, accounting for 8.6 and 13% of a seed mix (0.78 and 0.57% by weight), respectively.
#Text=Yarrow seeding rates were determined as part of a mix targeting a site appropriate total number of seeds per area.
#Text=Sites were drill seeded with a Truax Roughrider no_till rangeland seed drill, which cut furrows approximately 1.9 cm deep (Truax Corp., Minneapolis, MN, U.S.A.).
#Text=A nearby weather station recorded similar precipitation (149�157 mm) between March and November during the initial growing season of each seeding.
#Text=In November 2019, 11 ha were re_seeded with a diverse mix (Table S3c) in the Older site to increase diversity and cover after yarrow declined.
#Text=Root and Soil Sampling\rIn June 2020, we dug up yarrow plants from 10 randomly chosen locations at both sites and collected roots and soil adhered to yarrow roots (0�15 cm depth).

#Text=Soil samples were sieved (2 mm), freeze_dried (Labconco Freezone benchtop freeze_dry system, Labconco, Kansas City, MO, U.S.A.), and stored at  20degreesC for future DNA extraction and amplification.

#Text=Yarrow fine roots (<1.5 mm diameter) from individual plants were rinsed in tap water, placed in a 1.5 mL microcentrifuge tube, freeze_dried, and homogenized using a 1600 MiniG tissue homogenizer and cell lyser (Spex SamplePrep, Metuchen, NJ, U.S.A.) before DNA extraction and amplification.

#Text=To compare fungal and oomycete communities in the rhizospheres of yarrow within the two restoration areas with naturally occurring yarrow, we also sampled fine roots from 10 randomly selected yarrow plants growing in a native community approximately 1 km northeast of the Older site (Fig�S1).
#Text=Vegetation Sampling\rIn June 2020, at 10 randomly selected locations at both sites, we used a 1   1 m frame to visually estimate plant canopy and ground cover (to the nearest 5% increment).
#Text=Species cover under 5% was assigned to 1%, and we used 0.1% to indicate trace cover presence below 1%.
#Text=Total cover could exceed 100% because overlapping cover was included.
#Text=To determine what replaced yarrow after its decline, we surveyed the same fixed plots (n = 10) at each site again in June, 2022.
#Text=To capture more variation and patchy species distribution, we also surveyed an additional 10 randomly located plots per site in 2022.

#Text=Field Experiment\rIn 2013, we established a large field experiment consisting of 448 plots (1.2   1.2 m with 1 m buffer) in a completely randomized design harboring different communities of seven natives and three non_native forbs treated with fungicide or not.
#Text=Details of the establishment and species composition in the experiment are in�Supplement S1, and initial nutrient availabilities and pH are in Table�S1.

#Text=To address questions 2 and 3, we focused on the 48 plots that harbored yarrow planted in community types consisting of (1) monocultures (32 yarrow seedlings), (2) dominant (20 yarrow seedlings and two seedlings each of six other native forb species), and (3) even (four seedlings each of yarrow and the six native forbs plus four randomly selected seedlings) communities.

#Text=Communities were established from seedlings grown from seeds (same source as above) in the greenhouse and inoculated with soil from nearby native and non_native communities to ensure the presence of diverse soil biota.
#Text=Communities were watered during the first summer to ensure good establishment.
#Text=Plots were weeded to remove non_planted species.
#Text=Fungicide was applied in September 2013 and then twice a year in April and October.

#Text=Fungicide_treated plots received a 1 L/m2�mixture of Ridomil Gold EC (Syngenta Corporation, Greensboro, NC, U.S.A.; 0.117 mL/L active ingredient mefenoxam) and Topsin 4.5FL (United Phosphorus, Inc., King of Prussia, PA, U.S.A.; 2.5 mL/L active ingredient thiophanate_methyl) applied with hand_wand from an all terrain vehicle�mounted tank.
#Text=Control plots received the same amount of water.

#Text=Starting in 2015 and annually thereafter, we estimated plant cover for species rooted within a 1 x 1 m quadrat at peak biomass at the end of June (three community types   two fungicide treatments   eight reps).

#Text=To determine if fungal and oomycete communities change over time and respond to fungicide applications, we collected soil samples from the 16 yarrow monoculture plots in 2014, 2016, and 2019, although samples were not collected from fungicided plots in 2016.
#Text=From each plot, we collected three soil cores (2.5 x 10 cm) randomly located within the plot but at least 15 cm from the edge.
#Text=The three cores were mixed into one composite sample per plot, freeze_dried, and stored in the freezer prior to DNA extractions.

#Text=Greenhouse Experiments\rDirect Effects of Fungicides\rTo determine if fungicides have direct beneficial or detrimental effects on yarrow, we grew yarrow in sterile soil that we then treated with fungicide or not.

#Text=On 31 October 2019, 2_week_old seedlings germinated on MiracleGro Seed Starting Potting Mix (Marysville, OH, U.S.A.) and grown from the same seed source as above were planted into 10 cm diameter pots containing 450 mL of a 1:1:1 soil:sand:turface (v:v:v) mixture.
#Text=Soil collected from the field experiment area was sterilized by three rounds of autoclaving (3   3 hours at 121degreesC).
#Text=Four days after planting, 20 mL of the same fungicide mixture used in the field was added to half the pots, and the other half received water.
#Text=The volume was based on the surface area of the pot to ensure that the same amount of fungicide was used in the greenhouse and the field.
#Text=This application was repeated on 10 December, 44 days after planting.

#Text=Due to yellowing of leaves indicating nitrogen deficiency in both treatments, we fertilized all plants with 20 mL of a 0.5 g/L of 20.2.20 (N_P_K, Peters Professional fertilizer, JR Peters, Inc., Allentown, PA, U.S.A.) solution four times during the experiment, starting 27 days after planting and then every other week.
#Text=Plants were harvested on 16 January 2020, 11 weeks after planting.
#Text=Shoot biomass (all biomass above the soil surface) was recorded after drying at 65degreesC until constant weight.

#Text=Pathogen Spread\rTo assess if the pathogens associated with the suppression of yarrow in the field could negatively affect other native forbs (question 4), we conducted a plant�soil feedback study.

#Text=In a greenhouse, we grew Blanketflower (Gaillardia aristata), Lewis flax (Linum lewisii), Maximilian sunflower (Helianthus maximiliani), and Upright prairie coneflower (Ratibida columnifera) in soils that had previously harbored yarrow.
#Text=To generate the yarrow_trained soil inoculum, we planted yarrow seedlings on 6 November 2019 in 10 cm diameter pots containing a 1:1:1 soil:sand:turface mixture.

#Text=The soil fraction was harvested from eight heterospecific monoculture plots (two plots each of Hairy golden aster [Heterotheca villosa], Sticky cinquefoil [Drymocallis glandulosa], Leafy spurge [Euphorbia esula], and Sulfur cinquefoil [Potentilla recta]) from the large field experiment outlined above and in�Supplement S1�to ensure a diverse mixture of soil fungi but where no prior training by yarrow had occurred (Fig�S2).

#Text=Soil from each field plot was divided into two pots, one receiving water and one receiving fungicide (same amount and concentration as above), which was added on 12 November and 17 December 2019.
#Text=All 16 pots were fertilized twice monthly using the same concentrations and volumes as above when assessing the direct effects of fungicides.

#Text=On 6 April 2020, we cut the shoots at the soil surface, removed coarser roots to prevent re_growth, and replanted yarrow seedlings to condition soils twice to increase the likelihood of pathogen build_up.
#Text=Plants were grown as before, and fungicide or water was applied on 4 May and 2 June 2020.
#Text=Plants were harvested on 20 July 2020, and shoot biomass was dried as before.

#Text=On 4 August 2020, we added 70 mL of either yarrow control or yarrow fungicide inoculum on top of the same sterilized soil:sand:turface (1:1:1) mix as before into 200 mL containers and planted seeds.
#Text=Thus, in total, we had 64 pots (4 species   2 inocula   8 replicates).
#Text=Pots were watered as needed and fertilized as before.
#Text=Maximilian sunflower seeds had very low germination, so this species was omitted from the study.
#Text=Shoot biomass of the remaining species was harvested on 1 October 2020.

#Text=DNA Extraction, Amplification, and Bioinformatics\rWe used the Dneasy PowerSoil Pro DNA isolation kit (Qiagen) for DNA extraction from soil, roots, and control samples containing no roots or soil.
#Text=Samples were prepared for Illumina sequencing through a two_step Polymerase Chain Reaction amplification.
#Text=We amplified the internal transcribed spacer 2 (ITS2) for general fungi and internal transcribed spacer 1 (ITS1) for oomycetes in all soil and root samples.
#Text=We amplified the ITS2 region using a mix of forward fungal primers flITS7 and flITS7o and the reverse primer ITS4, following Bullington et al (2018).
#Text=For the ITS1 region, we used the forward primer OOM18S (Legeay et al�2019) and the reverse primer ITS7ae, a degenerate form of ITS7 (Taheri et al�2017).
#Text=Samples were assigned unique barcodes and pooled based on band strength.
#Text=Sequencing was performed at the University of Montana Genomics Core (umt.edu/genomics_lab/; Missoula, MT, U.S.A.).
#Text=Amplicon libraries were sequenced using 2   300 paired end reads on the Illumina MiSeq platform (Illumnia Inc).
#Text=All sequences have been submitted to Sequence Read Archive on National Center for Biotechnology Information under accession number PRJNA983826.
#Text=Oomycete communities did not amplify well from roots and soil in the field survey and were therefore not assessed.
#Text=Raw sequence data was processed using QIIME 2 (version 2018.4; Caporaso et al�2010).
#Text=For the ITS2 gene, forward and reverse reads were trimmed when median quality score fell below 30, which was 200 bp for the forward reads and 240 bp for the reverse reads.
#Text=For the ITS1 gene, reverse reads were trimmed to 240 bp.

#Text=Only reverse reads were used for the ITS1 amplicons, as the forward reads covered the 18S rDNA region, which lacks nucleotide polymorphisms needed to distinguish oomycete species (Legeay et al�2019).
#Text=The q2_dada2 plugin was used to produce sequence clusters with 100% similarity.

#Text=Because we were interested in taxonomic rather than genetic resolution, and because functionality of fungi is often conserved at the level of genus or family (Tedersoo et al�2022), we clustered the sequences at 97% similarity using the q2_vsearch plugin de novo to produce operational taxonomic units (OTUs).
#Text=The database UNITE (Nilsson et al�2019) was used to assign taxonomy to representative fungal and oomycete sequences.
#Text=We then used the database FUNGuild to assign potential function to all OTUs that were assigned taxonomy (Nguyen et al�2016).

#Text=We used all OTUs identified as  highly probable   and  probable   plant pathogens to represent the plant pathogen community, which should be considered putative pathogens as it is uncertain if they cause disease in our system and conditions.
#Text=Analysis of fungal and oomycete communities was rarified using sequence depth curves before statistical analysis to 4000 and 1000 sequences per sample using the q2_diversity plugin.

#Text=Samples with fewer sequences were removed to allow for a greater sequencing depth, leaving 20 out of 20 soil samples and 25 out of 30 yarrow root samples (Older,�n = 7; Younger,�n = 8; and Native,�n = 10) in the field survey and 39 of 40 soil samples from the field experiment.
#Text=Also, an average of 59% of OTUs across samples was assigned putative function in FUNGuild.

#Text=Statistical Analyses\rField Survey\rTo determine if mean absolute yarrow cover differed between the two restoration sites, we used a Welch�t_test since data were normally distributed but had unequal variance.
#Text=Field Experiment\rWe assessed the effect of the fungicide treatment on percent cover of yarrow in the different communities over time visually and using a linear_mixed effects model.

#Text=Our full model included fungicide application, community (i.e. monoculture, dominant, or even), year_since_planting, and community by year interaction as fixed effects and plot id as a random effect to account for repeated measures (cover ~ fungicide +�community + year + community   year + 1|plot).
#Text=We built this model from a null model of effect (cover ~ year + 1|plot), adding terms sequentially.
#Text=Models were fit using maximum likelihood estimation via  lmer from the lme4 package (Bates et al�2015).
#Text=Residuals were visually examined for normality and homoscedasticity.
#Text=We used  anova.merMod   to run a likelihood ratio test of all models, which confirmed that the full model explained more variance than the reduced models.

#Text=We then tested each coefficient from the full model in a type III analysis of variance (ANOVA) with Satterthwaite's degrees of freedom method via  anova.lmerModLmerTest  from the lmerTest package (Kuznetsova et al�2017).
#Text=Finally, we did a pairwise comparison across communities using  emmeans   from the emmeans package (Lenth�2024).
#Text=We present the data as mean and 95% CIs (t_distribution) of cover for each community by fungicide by year combination.
#Text=Greenhouse Experiments\rWe tested for a direct effect of fungicide on yarrow by comparing total plant biomass from the fungicide and control treatment using a two_sample�t_test.

#Text=We looked for potential pathogen carry_over to restoration species with a two_way ANOVA to examine the main effects and interactions of (1) fungicide: treated and untreated control and (2) restoration species: Blanketflower, coneflower, and flax on the shoot biomass of restoration plants.
#Text=Data met assumptions of normality and homogeneity of variance by Levene and Shapiro�Wilk tests.
#Text=All analyses were performed with R Software (version 4.2.2; R Core Team�2021).
#Text=Fungal and Oomycete Communities\rDifferences in community compositions were analyzed in R using the vegan package (Oksanen et al�2019) unless noted otherwise.
#Text=We used the vegdist function based on OTU sequence abundance and Bray�Curtis distances to calculate dissimilarity.
#Text=We performed non_metric multidimensional scaling using the metaMDS function to visualize changes to the fungal and oomycete communities (k = 2).
#Text=We tested whether OTU composition differed among plant pathogen communities via permutational multivariate ANOVA (perMANOVA; Anderson�2017) and adonis2 function.
#Text=Dispersion of points among groups was tested using the betadispers function.
#Text=We used sequence abundance as a measure of the relative abundance of putative pathogens.
#Text=While this may not reflect absolute abundance due to differences in gene copy numbers among taxa and primer bias (e.g.

#Text=Corradi et al�2007; Kohout et al�2014), sequence numbers have been shown to correlate well with abundant taxa (Skelton et al�2022), and any potential discrepancies in our approach should apply equally to all samples.
#Text=To test for differences in relative pathogen sequence abundance, we used ANOVA.
#Text=Normality and equal variance assumptions were assessed visually.
#Text=Lastly, to locate potential indicator species using relative sequence abundances of plant pathogen OTUs, we used the indval function in the labdsv package (Roberts�2019).
#Text=Results.

#Text=Field Survey of Restoration Sites\rDespite being a minor component (<15% by seed number) of the overall seed mix, yarrow was the dominant species in both restoration sites 5 and 3 years after seeding, although yarrow cover was lower in the Older site than the Younger site (p < 0.006).
#Text=In contrast, perennial grasses, sown at a higher abundance (>45%), exhibited much lower coverage relative to their initial seeding density (<13%; Tables�S2�& S3; Fig�2B�&�2D).
#Text=By 2022, relative yarrow cover dwindled to <5% in both sites (Table�S2; Fig�2B�&�2D).
#Text=Thus, yarrow established rapidly and outperformed other species in the seed mix but declined dramatically 5�7 years after planting.
#Text=Figure 2\rThe proportion of species seeded (A) and their relative cover (B) in the Older site.
#Text=(C) and (D) show the Younger site.

#Text=In 2022, there were 35 total species, of which 2 were seeded non_native, 8 were seeded native, 10 were unseeded native, and 15 unseeded_non_native species at the 5_year post_seeding, Younger site.

#Text=At the Older site, 7 years after the first seeding and 3 years following the additional seeding, there were 58 total species, of which were 12 seeded native, 15 unseeded native, and 31 unseeded_non_native species.
#Text=The lower yarrow cover in the Older site coincided with a higher relative abundance of fungal pathogens (F[2,22] Site = 17.25,�p < 0.001; Fig�3B).
#Text=Across all sites, we identified 609 and 577 fungal OTUs in soil and roots, respectively, of which 74 and 66 OTUs were probable or highly probable plant pathogens.

#Text=The composition of pathogens in yarrow roots also differed among sites (F[2,22] Site = 6.8,�r2 = 0.38,�p = 0.001; Fig�3A), with less clear differences in the soil (F[1,19] Site = 1.8,�r2 = 0.09,�p = 0.07; Fig�S3).
#Text=Overall, roots in the Older site harbored pathogens that were more dissimilar from the native site than the Younger site.

#Text=This pattern was similar when repeating the analysis on presence�absence data (Jaccard:�r2 = 0.09,�F[2,22]Site = 5.69,�p = 0.001), suggesting sites harbored different taxa, not just variations in relative abundance.

#Text=Figure 3\rCommunities (A), relative abundance (B), and correlation (C) of putative fungal pathogens in yarrow roots collected in 2020 from the then 3_year post_seeding Younger and 5_year post_seeding Older restoration sites as well as from native yarrow growing in an adjacent community (see Fig�S1�for location), including root rot_causing�Paraphoma�spp.
#Text=Error bars show mean +/_ SE, Older site,�n = 7; Younger site,�n = 8; and Native,�n = 10.
#Text=The 95% CI for the mean is shown as a light gray band surrounding the line.
#Text=An indicator species analysis revealed that an OTU identified as�Paraphoma�spp was preferentially associated with the Older site (F[1,13]Site = 32.51,�p < 0.001; Fig�3B).

#Text=To ensure this result was not driven by responses of other taxa, we ran an analysis of composition of microbiomes (ANCOM), which controls for false discovery rate and potential biases associated with compositional data (Weiss et al�2017).

#Text=This additional analysis on absolute sequence abundance also showed significant difference between the Older and Younger site (W =  3.72,�p = 0.002), suggesting our indicator species analysis was robust.

#Text=�Paraphoma�  spp are known to cause crown_rot (Moslemi et al�2016), and the closest match in NCBI with our OTU was with�Paraphoma chrysanthemicola�(accession number MT596045.1;�www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov).
#Text=�Paraphoma�  spp relative abundance correlated negatively with yarrow cover across both sites in 2020 (r =  0.54,�t[13] =  2.4,�p = 0.034; Fig�3C).
#Text=In 2022, plant communities differed in the Older and Younger sites.

#Text=At the Older site, unseeded_non_native grasses and forbs (>60% canopy cover) filled the niche space left open by yarrow's decline, with an increase in native perennial grass canopy coverage from approximately 10% in 2020 to approximately 30% in 2022 (Fig�2B).
#Text=At the Younger site, yarrow's rapid decline between 2020 and 2022 coincided with a dominance by  Don   variety alfalfa (Medicago sativa�L. ssp�Falcata�[L.]
#Text=Arcang), and an increase in unseeded_non_native grasses and forbs (Fig�2D).
#Text=Field Experiment\rFungicide increased yarrow cover across years and community types (F[1,48.6] = 28.8,�p < 0.001, Table S4a & S4b; Fig�4).
#Text=Peak cover differed among community types, with monocultures at approximately 100% cover 2 years after planting and even communities at approximately 50% cover 4 years after planting (Fig�4).
#Text=Cover in dominant communities varied, yet peak year and mean cover at peak fell between monoculture and even communities (Fig�4).

#Text=The significant interactions of community type by year in the full model (F[2,292.1] = 29.4,�p < 0.001; Table S4b) indicate that the rate of yarrow decline depended on community type; declining faster in monoculture plots relative to dominant plots (t53.6 = 4.2,�p = 0.003) and even plots (t53.6 = 7.0,�p < 0.001; Table S4c; Fig�4).

#Text=Thus, while yarrow cover eventually declined to approximately 0% by year 8 in all plots, the onset of this crash happened earlier and proceeded more rapidly in monoculture plots where yarrow density was highest.

#Text=Figure 4\rPercent cover of yarrow grown in field experiment, including monoculture, dominant, or even communities that were sprayed with fungicides (dark gray squares) or water (white circles) from 2 to 8 years after planting.
#Text=The 95% CIs for the means are shown as a light gray band surrounding each line.
#Text=Dashed lines correspond to the peak percent cover of yarrow,�n = 8 in each community type.
#Text=In all, we identified 547 fungal OTUs, of which 77 were classified as probable or highly probable pathogens.

#Text=We found that communities of putative pathogens differed between control and fungicided plots (F[1,34]Fungicide = 3.8,�r2 = 0.09,�p = 0.003; Fig�5A) and changed over time (F[2,34]Time = 1.9,�r2 = 0.09,�p = 0.03).
#Text=Similar significant results were obtained when analyzing presence/absence data (not shown), suggesting species turnover.

#Text=However, while fungicide affected the composition of putative pathogens, it did not affect their relative abundance (F[1,28] = 1.04,�p = 0.317; Fig�5B), which ranged from 30 to 36% of total fungal sequences.
#Text=Nor did the relative abundance of fungal pathogens increase with time (F[1,28] = 0.61,�p = 0.441).

#Text=However, focusing solely on�Paraphoma�  spp, the crown_rot pathogen that we detected in the field survey, we found that its relative abundance increased over time in control plots (F[2,34]Time = 7.13,�p = 0.002) and trended lower in fungicide plots (Fig�5).
#Text=Fifty_three oomycete OTUs were identified, but oomycete communities were not affected by fungicide applications and only differed marginally by year (F[2,34]Time = 1.8,�r2 = 0.10,�p = 0.08).

#Text=Figure 5\rNonmetric multidimensional scaling (NMDS) ordination of fungal pathogen communities in the field experiment and how they changed over time in control and fungicided yarrow monoculture plots (A) and relative sequence abundance of the indicator species�Paraphoma�sp. in the control and fungicided plots over time (B).
#Text=No samples were collected from fungicided plots in 2016.
#Text=Mean +/_ SE,�n = 8.

#Text=Greenhouse Experiment\rDirect Effects of Fungicides\rBiomass of yarrow grown in sterilized soil trended lower (t[14] = 1.7,�p = 0.101) in pots receiving fungicide (0.42 +/_ 0.04 g, mean +/_ SE) than pots receiving water (0.49 +/_ 0.02 g).
#Text=Thus, when yarrow was grown without soil biota, fungicide had either no effect or effects were opposite those found in the field.

#Text=Spread to Other Native Species\rIn the soil conditioning phase when yarrow was grown with soil biota, fungicide affected yarrow performance similar to the field (F[1,28] = 9.16,�p = 0.005), and shoot biomass was higher with fungicide (1.17 +/_ 0.07 g, mean +/_ SE) than without fungicide (0.67 +/_ 0.08 g).

#Text=Testing for pathogen spread, we found shoot biomass differed among the three species inoculated with yarrow_trained soil (F[2,37] = 3.46,�p = 0.04), but not between fungicide and controls (F[1,37] = 0.02,�p = 0.89; Fig�6).
#Text=There was no interaction between restoration species and fungicide treatment (F[2,37] = 0.82,�p = 0.45).
#Text=Thus, while fungicide promoted yarrow growth due to suppressive effects in control treatments, this suppressive effect was not transmitted to other species.
#Text=Figure 6\rShoot biomass of Blanketflower, coneflower, and flax grown in the greenhouse in yarrow_trained soil where either fungicide (black bars) or not (gray bars) was added.
#Text=There were no significant differences between control and fungicide treatments for any species.
#Text=Error bars show mean +/_ SE,�n = 8.
#Text=Discussion.
#Text=Predicting restoration success is notoriously difficult (Rinella et al�2012), indicating a need to better understand plant community development (Brudvig�2017; Zirbel et al�2017).

#Text=Surveys of restoration projects and a field experiment showed that a native forb, Western Yarrow, favored in restoration projects underwent boom and bust patterns that may be linked to a relative increase of a crown_rot pathogen.
#Text=Greenhouse experiments showed that the self_suppressive effect of yarrow on soil did not harm other native forbs commonly used in restoration.
#Text=Plant�soil feedback has predominately been studied in the greenhouse, where responses are often more negative than in the field (Kulmatiski et al�2008).

#Text=Our findings indicate that plant�soil feedbacks can be negative and strong outside of controlled greenhouse experiments, possibly due to the high host density (Liao et al�2015; Yang et al�2015) and multi_year conditioning, and that these effects can have implications for restoration success.

#Text=Rapid Decline in Yarrow Linked to Shifts in Fungal Pathogens\rWhen it comes to soil biota, restoration ecologists have centered their attention around mutualists (Asmelash et al�2016; Koziol & Bever�2017), whereas pathogens have received less attention.

#Text=This is unfortunate because pathogens can maintain diversity (Fitzsimons & Miller�2010; van Ruijven et al�2020) and reduce the life span, fecundity, and competitive ability of early successional plants (Kardol et al�2006), especially when grown in high densities (Kulmatiski et al�2012; Bauer et al�2017).
#Text=One exception is the use of pathogens to control cheatgrass, although it has had little success as a management practice so far (Dooley & Beckstead�2010; Reinhart et al�2020).
#Text=To our knowledge, the possibility of managing naturally occurring pathogens to aid in restoration has not yet been explored.
#Text=Here, we present data suggesting the rapid decline of yarrow is at least partly due to fungal pathogens.
#Text=First, the lower yarrow cover in the Older restoration site coincided with a higher relative abundance of putative pathogens, consistent with pathogen suppression.

#Text=This was especially true for�Paraphoma�  spp a basidiomycete that causes crown_rot in several forbs (Moslemi et al�2016; Cao et al�2020), and that has been found in yarrow roots and rhizosphere soil previously (Sch�ps et al�2018; Ampt et al�2022).
#Text=In fact, Francioli et al (2020) found�Paraphoma chrysanthemicola�the closest match with the�Paraphoma�in our study�in a common garden growing yarrow in the Netherlands.
#Text=Second, throughout the 10_year field experiment, yarrow cover was higher in plots receiving fungicide, and yarrow also grew better in soils receiving fungicide in the greenhouse.

#Text=While unintended fungicide effects can complicate interpretations (Paul et al�1989; Burdon et al�2006), our greenhouse experiment showed the beneficial effect on yarrow was mediated by soil biota, because fungicide promoted growth of yarrow only when soil biota was present but not when fungicide was added to sterile soil.

#Text=Fungicides can also increase fungal necromass, resulting in higher nutrient availabilities, but this is unlikely to have caused the promotion of growth and cover in fungicided plots because (1) fungicides more often change the composition of fungi rather than suppress overall biomass (Helgason et al�2007; Henning et al�2018), and (2) nutrient availabilities in the experimental plots were high and pots in the greenhouse were fertilized regularly.
#Text=Also, the fungicide used here has previously been shown to promote plant productivity, but only in low diversity plots (Maron et al�2011).
#Text=This was most likely due to density_dependent pathogen accumulation, which has been shown before across a range of native species (Mommer et al�2018; Liu et al�2022).
#Text=Because we only assessed fungal communities in monoculture communities, we cannot determine if the relative pathogen abundance increased with yarrow density.
#Text=However, the more rapid onset of yarrow decline in monoculture plots than in plots with lower yarrow density is consistent with density_dependence.
#Text=While the increased performance of yarrow with fungicides indicates a suppressive role of pathogenic fungi, yarrow ultimately declined in fungicided plots also.
#Text=This particular yarrow cultivar may not live long in our area, or fungicide applications may not suppress all fungi, which has been reported previously (Henning et al�2018).

#Text=Indeed, even though the composition of fungi changed, fatty acid analyses of fungal biomass in control and fungicided plots revealed only modest declines in fungal biomass over time (Lekberg, unpublished data), possibly because we only applied fungicide twice a year or it was incorporated insufficiently into the soil.
#Text=This ineffective control by fungicides was supported by brownish_black roots of the few yarrow plants remaining in fungicided plots in the field experiment (Lekberg, personal observation).
#Text=Irrespective, results from the survey and experimental plots combined suggest a potential role of soil pathogens in the substantial decline in yarrow cover.
#Text=Contrary to fungal pathogens, oomycetes amplified poorly or showed no treatment effects in our various studies.

#Text=This is unsurprising given that our experiments/restoration took place in semiarid soils, which may not provide the high soil moisture required for oomycete zoospore germination and spread (Raaijmakers et al�2009).

#Text=Considering Yarrow as a Bridge Species During Restoration\rBridge species are often early successional, competitive, and short_lived plants that facilitate the establishment of native plant species during restoration (Herron et al�2001; Meissen et al�2020).

#Text=Native plants can benefit from a bridge species' ruderal qualities in a pattern mimicking succession where longer_lived perennials are indirectly facilitated by the competitive but short_lived transition species (Sheley et al�2006; Perry et al�2009; Leger et al�2014).
#Text=Without a predictable die_off, herbicide, mowing, harvesting, or some other management intervention (Milchunas et al�2011; Espeland & Perkins�2013) are often required to remove bridge species.
#Text=The high initial cover and unmanaged rapid decline in yarrow highlight its potential as a bridge species.
#Text=Because we seeded yarrow in both restoration projects, we cannot quantify its effect as a bridge species, but we can speculate on its potential.

#Text=In our area, yarrow behaved as a ruderal, early successional species with the highest cover coinciding with a fractional proportion of non_native weeds 3 years after seeding in the Younger site, with seeded species making up most of the relative cover 5 years after seeding.
#Text=Because the decline of yarrow might have been mediated by pathogens, another requirement to be a bridge species is that pathogens are host_specific.

#Text=The greenhouse experiment showed that yarrow was suppressed when grown in its own soil without fungicides and that the suppressive effect was not transmitted to other native plants grown in yarrow_trained soil.

#Text=While the build_up of yarrow_specific fungal pathogens parsimoniously explains results, we cannot exclude other factors as we did not verify higher pathogen abundance in the soil without fungicides.
#Text=Also, recent work suggests yarrow promotes�Paraphoma�abundance in heterospecific neighbors in the Asteraceae family (Ampt et al�2022).

#Text=Inoculations with�Paraphoma, which we isolated from yarrow roots (DuPre, unpublished data), onto a range of native species across sites are required to unequivocally assess the degree of host specificity and generality of our findings.
#Text=What happens after bridge species declines determines the success or failure of a restoration project.
#Text=At the Younger site, non_native invasives nearly doubled, and unseeded_non_natives dominated at the Older site 7 years after seeding, tripling their relative cover between years 5 and 7.
#Text=Thus, while the Older site harbored long_lived native perennials such as arrowleaf balsamroot, silky lupine, and Idaho fescue, yarrow was mostly replaced by non_natives.
#Text=Future projects specifically testing yarrow as a bridge species are required to assess its ability to suppress non_native plants and influence the trajectory of native plant reestablishment.
#Text=In summary, this study indicates the value of incorporating plant�soil feedback into restoration ecology.
#Text=By expanding the focus from competition theory to consider plant�soil feedbacks, we may enhance our understanding and increase predictability of ecosystem restoration.

#Text=MPG Ranch provided support in each part of this study, and we especially appreciate the hard work of MPG Ranch's field crew, restoration, and experiment maintenance teams.
#Text=MPG Ranch provided funding and made the study possible.
